mapper.formattedText:
Before the colonization of Africa by European powers, Black people were known as members of the Tribe of Judah. One of the largest slave ports in West Africa—where many of our ancestors were taken—was labeled the Kingdom of Judah.

A 1747 map of Africa, created by English cartographer Edward Bowen, specifically shows this region. This map is available on the website of the Library of Congress. The Kingdom of Judah, now called Benin, was once West Africa’s largest slave port.

According to a publication by the University of Montpellier in the 1870s titled "Essai de Géographie Humaine", the area was a hub for the transatlantic slave trade. The port, known as the Kingdom of Judah, was the largest exporter of enslaved people, many of whom were from this very region.

The book mentions that Judah was an old city, frequented since the 16th century by Portuguese slave traders who gave it its name. Its inhabitants were described as Judaic, believed to be remnants of the scattered tribes of Israel. In other words, the Black people stolen from West Africa and brought to the Americas were Israelites—descendants of the ancient Kingdom of Judah.

messages.content: Act as a professional video script editor. Review and verify that the script you just produced is written so that the created video is at least 30 seconds but not more than 59 seconds, and that the narration follows the input text exactly—word for word and line for line.
